newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Singapore shares end weaker, focus on new issues.
newsitem.headline: Singapore shares end weaker, focus on new issues.

text.p: Singapore shares ended weaker on Friday spurred by profit-taking, with newly-issued stocks taking centre-stage, fuelled by speculative interest.

New and small capitalisation issues were most active, with debut stock Second Chance garnering highest volume at 42 million shares. The stock went on an early ascent to Singapore $0.60, up from its S$0.30 issue price, and then fell back to S$0.515.
Lung Kee Metal also drew interest, hitting a high of US$0.81, up from its issue price of $0.55 and ended at $0.78.
The 30-share Straits Times Industrials Index (STII) closed at 2,242.71, down 5.63 points.
Volume was a robust 250 million shares with a total of 142 stocks rising and 232 stocks falling.
"Funds got active in some of the new shares, like Lung Kee, because analysts called buying at these levels," a dealer with a local securities firm said.
Among the gainers was Malaysian stockbroking firm Rashid Hussain, which put on S$0.60 to S$11.50 as investors bet on its recent stake in an Indonesian bank.
Banks were broadly weaker with UOB Foreign down S$0.70 to $16.50, and OCBC Foreign down S$0.60 to $18.80.
